channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Explosions Over the Kremlin Set Off Dueling Accusations
item.description: Russia accused Ukraine of launching drones at the Kremlin aimed at killing President Vladimir V. Putin. The Ukrainian president denied the claim, and officials in Kyiv warned that Russia could use it to launch “a large-scale terrorist provocation.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: Fleeing Sudan, Some Find Saudi Ships ‘a Golden Opportunity’ to Escape
item.description: A Sudanese student waiting to be evacuated by Saudi Arabia counted himself as one of the lucky ones: Born in the kingdom and holding a residency permit, he could board a rescue ship.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: A Saudi evacuee from Sudan disembarking at the Jeddah port in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday.

item.title: $59 Million, Gone: How Bikini Atoll Leaders Blew Through U.S. Trust Fund
item.description: The Trump administration lifted spending limits on the fund, which aids descendants of people forced to leave the coral reef because of U.S. nuclear testing.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:description: Residents crossing between islands during a rising tide on Majuro, Marshall Islands, in 2015. Majuro is home to former residents of Bikini Atoll who were relocated in the 1940s.

item.title: 8 Students Killed After School Shooting in Belgrade, Serbia
item.description: The assailant had two pistols, four Molotov cocktails and detailed plans, the police said. A security guard was also killed.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Vladimir Zivojinovic for The New York Times

item.title: Brazil’s Police Raid Bolsonaro Home in Fake Vaccine Cards Case
item.description: The authorities arrested a close aide of former President Jair Bolsonaro on charges that he forged vaccine records, possibly to help Mr. Bolsonaro enter the United States.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance and Ana Ionova
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, the former president of Brazil, speaking to reporters outside his home in Brasília after the police search on Wednesday.

item.title: Belarus Opposition Activist Whose Flight Was Forced Down Is Sentenced to 8 Years
item.description: Roman Protasevich, who organized protests against the authoritarian leader of Belarus, was arrested after the authorities forced a commercial flight to land in the capital.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media of Roman Protasevich in Belarus in 2021.

item.title: Floods and Landslides Kill More Than 120 in Rwanda
item.description: Many areas across East Africa have in recent years experienced both severe droughts and heavy rainfalls that killed many and damaged property and crops.
item.dc:creator: Arafat Mugabo and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: A broken footbridge over a swollen river on Wednesday in western Rwanda.

item.title: Secret ‘Mission’ for Peace in Ukraine May Show Limits of Pope’s Influence
item.description: Since Francis made cryptic reference to a Vatican peace effort, the suggestion has elicited denial or bewilderment by war’s protagonists.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis waves to attendees as he arrives in the popemobile car for the weekly general audience at St. Peter’s square in the Vatican, on Wednesday.

item.title: Britain’s New Voter ID Rules Are Raising Hackles
item.description: Critics say the Conservative government’s new requirements are meant to discourage voting by young people and members of minority groups, who are likely to be Labour voters.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters in many countries have to show ID, but the change in Britain has unleashed a political storm ahead of municipal elections on Thursday.

item.title: Charles’s Coronation Brings Up Mixed Feelings About the British Monarchy
item.description: The divide in Bristol goes a long way toward explaining the substantial split in public opinion about the role the royals play in a modern Britain.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children at a tea and cake stall during a King Charles lll coronation celebration in Shirehampton, a part of northwestern Bristol, England, on Saturday.

item.title: The ‘Peace Dividend’ Is Over in Europe. Now Come the Hard Tradeoffs.
item.description: Defending against an unpredictable Russia in years to come will mean bumping up against a strained social safety net and ambitious climate transition plans.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Brandenburg Gate in Berlin. Last year, military spending in Europe had its biggest annual rise in three decades, the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute reported.

item.title: For King Charles, Coronation Day Is a Step on a Tightrope Walk
item.description: Britain’s head of state is said to want a more accessible, forward-looking and inclusive monarchy. It’s not an easy message to convey through golden relics and ancient rituals.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: King Charles III believes the British royal family “has to be shown to be useful,” one expert said.

item.title: Marcos Makes Mark on Foreign Policy in Push for Closer U.S.-Philippines Ties
item.description: In his first months in power, the Philippines leader has reforged a strong alliance with the U.S., winning praise even as questions remain about his path and intent at home.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: President Joe Biden and the first lady, Dr. Jill Biden, greeting President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. of the Philippines and his wife, Louise Araneta-Marcos, at the White House on Monday.

item.title: A Brutal Sex Trade Built for American Soldiers
item.description: It’s a long-buried part of South Korean history: women compelled by force, trickery or desperation into prostitution, with the complicity of their own leaders.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Jean Chung
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: In Dongducheon, South Korea, north of Seoul, women forced to work as prostitutes to American soldiers in the decades after the Korean War were confined in this building when they were discovered to have a sexually transmitted disease.

item.title: His Cousin Promised a Quake-Proof Building. Then the Walls Crumbled.
item.description: Turkish families got wealthy off a construction system rife with patronage. A Times investigation reveals just how fatally shaky that system was.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Nimet Kirac
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The collapsed Guclu Bahce complex in Antakya, Turkey, in March.

item.title: Bluster over explosions raises fears of retaliation by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: A police car on the edge of Red Square in Moscow on Wednesday, after two drones had exploded over the Kremlin in the early-morning hours.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Accusations of an assassination attempt on Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A still image of what appeared to be a drone exploding above the Kremlin.

item.title: With Local Elections in Much of the U.K., Here’s What’s at Stake
item.description: Municipalities across England will face voters, including in areas that could sway the next national election. Here’s a guide to the ballots and how to interpret them.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A voting site from local elections in England last year. Voters in the country will elect around 8,000 representatives in lower tiers of government on Thursday.

item.title: Explosions Above Kremlin Were an Attempt to Kill Putin, Russia Claims
item.description: Russia said Ukraine had launched a drone attack, which Kyiv vehemently denied, accusing Russia of manufacturing a pretext for escalation.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Haley Willis
item.media:description: Russian law enforcement officers standing guard in Red Square in Moscow on Wednesday. Two drones detonated above the Kremlin earlier in the day.

item.title: Congress Clashes With Biden Over Tariffs on Illegal Chinese Solar Panels
item.description: In a rebuke to the Biden administration, the Senate approved a measure to reinstate tariffs on solar panels found to violate U.S. trade rules.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Biden administration sees mitigating climate change as among its most important priorities.

item.title: Zelensky Arrives in the Netherlands to Speak at The Hague, Dutch Media Reports
item.description: The Ukrainian president has long urged that Vladimir Putin and others be held to account under international law.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is in the Netherlands to make an address at The Hague on Thursday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Explosions over the Kremlin
item.description: Also, American miscalculations in Sudan.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Part of the Kremlin complex, next to the Moskva River, in Moscow on Wednesday.

item.title: Zelensky Denies Ukraine Carried Out the Drone Attack on the Kremlin
item.description: The Ukrainian president flatly denied that his country was behind any drone attack on the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola
item.media:credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, center, during a news conference with Nordic leaders in Helsinki, Finland, on Wednesday.

item.title: The U.S. Is ‘Intensely Engaged’ in Efforts to Free Evan Gershkovich, Blinken Says
item.description: The Wall Street Journal reporter has been held for more than a month on espionage charges that the United States considers bogus.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in Washington in March.

item.title: Verified Videos Show Two Drones Exploding Over the Kremlin in Russia
item.description: The explosions were separated by about 15 minutes and one caused a brief fire.
item.dc:creator: Haley Willis and Riley Mellen
item.media:description: Russian law enforcement officers standing guard in Red Square in Moscow on Wednesday. Two drones detonated above the Kremlin earlier in the day.

item.title: What Is the Kremlin, the Heart of Putin’s Security Bubble in Russia?
item.description: The Russian president resides at various heavily guarded locations and travels frequently between Moscow and a compound in an elite suburb miles away.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: The Kremlin complex sits in the center of Moscow, and contains the Russian president’s official residence and main office.

item.title: A South Korean Horror Story, Long Suppressed
item.description: The story of a brutal sex trade built for American soldiers shows how women have been exploited in service of political and economic goals.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cho Soon-ok, a former comfort woman for G.I.s, standing outside a former detention center in South Korea.

item.title: RSV Vaccine Approved for Older Adults
item.description: The shots would be the first vaccines available against a respiratory virus that kills thousands and leads to many more hospitalizations each year.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: An transmission electron microscopic image of R.S.V.

item.title: Why Did Russia Choose to Publicize the Kremlin Drone Attack?
item.description: Russia’s messaging on a drone incident at the Kremlin diverged significantly from its response to past explosions in Russia or Russian-occupied territory.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Russian police officers stationed outside the Kremlin in Moscow on Wednesday.

item.title: Serbia School Attack Is a Rare Mass Shooting Outside the U.S.
item.description: The attack in Belgrade, which killed eight people, was the first mass shooting in the country in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Police officers were on the street in Belgrade after a school shooting on Wednesday.

item.title: Sultan al-Jaber, Who Heads U.N. Climate Talks, Hints at His Approach
item.description: In a speech, Sultan al-Jaber, the Emirati official presiding over this year’s climate summit, spoke of emissions cuts, but experts also cited ambiguity in his statements.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Bernd Von Jutrczenka/DPA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sultan al-Jaber called for a tripling of renewable energy capacity this decade and said the world was “way off track” in meeting its emissions reductions pledges.

item.title: How U.S. Efforts to Guide Sudan to Democracy Ended in War
item.description: Critics say the Biden administration and its partners were naïve about the intentions of two rival generals and failed to empower civilian leaders.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Michael Crowley and Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Gueipeur Denis Sassou/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Sudanese refugees who crossed into Chad preparing temporary shelters on Sunday. The fighting in Sudan has displaced more than 330,000 people.

item.title: The Debt Ceiling and False Equivalence
item.description: The outcome of the debt ceiling conflict is genuinely uncertain.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Kevin McCarthy speaking to the press after passing a debt ceiling bill in the House last week.

item.title: Zelensky Travels to Finland to Meet With Nordic Leaders
item.description: The Ukrainian president has made few overseas trips since Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and Enjoli Liston
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, left, and President Sauli Niinisto of Finland at a welcoming ceremony at the Presidential Palace in Helsinki on Wednesday.

item.title: The President, the Soccer Hooligans and an Underworld ‘House of Horrors’
item.description: A grisly trial in Serbia has raised questions about connections between the country’s top leadership and its violent drug gangs.
item.dc:creator: Robert F. Worth
item.media:description: President Aleksandar Vucic of Serbia in 2021.

item.title: ‘A New Spike’ in Global Temperatures in the Forecast
item.description: The World Meteorological Organization reports increased odds that El Niño, the global weather pattern often tied to intense heat, will arrive by fall.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:description: The London skyline at sunrise during a heat wave in August. Worldwide, the last eight years have been the hottest on record.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Russian pressure on civilians in occupied Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Russian police officer at a polling station during a September referendum in the Luhansk People’s Republic. It is controlled by Russian-backed separatists.

item.title: Russia Ramps Up Pressure on Civilians in Occupied Ukraine
item.description: Wary of Ukrainian partisans and anticipating a counteroffensive, Russian authorities have “reinforced” counterintelligence units in occupied territory, Ukraine says.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A Russian police officer at a polling station during a September referendum in the Luhansk People’s Republic. It is controlled by Russian-backed separatists.

item.title: Explosion Reportedly Derails Another Train in Russia Near Ukraine Border
item.description: An explosion on Tuesday in Bryansk, along Ukraine’s northern border, sent a locomotive and about 20 train cars off the rails, local authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar

item.title: Man Arrested Outside Buckingham Palace as Police Conduct Controlled Explosion
item.description: Ahead of King Charles III’s coronation, a man threw what police called suspected shotgun cartridges onto the palace grounds, and a bag he carried was detonated as a precaution.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Security forces stand guard after British police arrested a man outside Buckingham Palace on Tuesday.

item.title: What to Know About Hunger Strikes
item.description: The actions are almost always political, and governments sometimes resort to force-feeding, a practice denounced as inhumane. Deaths like that of a Palestinian prisoner this week are uncommon.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Relatives of Khader Adnan, a Palestinian Islamic Jihad militant who died in an Israeli prison after a nearly three-month hunger strike, mourned at his family home in the West Bank village of Arrabe, near Jenin, on Tuesday.

item.title: One Dose of HPV Vaccine Prevents Infection for at Least Three Years
item.description: Protection may last even longer, scientists reported. The finding may be a boon to low-income countries, where cervical cancer takes an enormous toll.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli

item.title: Australia Aims to ‘Stamp Out’ Vaping With Sweeping Regulations
item.description: The proposal would ban all single-use, disposable vapes, halt the importation of nonprescription vapes and restrict certain flavors, colors and ingredients.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:description: Mark Butler, Australia’s health minister, said the focus of the initiative was to “shut down a major health risk to the youngest generation of Australians.”

item.title: New York Times’s Publisher Warns of Risks to Press Freedom and Democracy
item.description: The free press’s role in supporting human rights and democratic societies is “at great risk” amid increasing levels of violence against journalists worldwide, A.G. Sulzberger said.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Christopher Mele
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter, was detained by Russian authorities in March on charges of espionage. He is one of hundreds of journalists currently in custody around the world.

item.title: Sudan’s Warring Generals Agree to Weeklong Truce, Says South Sudan
item.description: The battle has sent 100,000 refugees fleeing across borders. Now, neighboring South Sudan says both sides have agreed to name representatives to peace talks, but neither side has publicly confirmed.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Gueipeur Denis Sassou/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Refugees from Sudan in Chad on Sunday. Many of Sudan’s neighbors are reeling from their own economic, political and refugee crises.

item.title: How First Republic and Other Bank Failures Could Impact the U.S. Economy
item.description: Are we on the brink of a financial crisis — or has the threat been contained?
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Ian C. Bates for The New York Times
item.media:description: Regulators seized control of First Republic Bank and sold it to JPMorgan Chase yesterday.

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Rises as Policymakers Weigh a Rate Increase
item.description: The annual rate of inflation reached 7 percent, but the underlying “core” rate eased for the first time in 10 months.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A supermarket in Berlin. Prices for food in the eurozone rose 13.6 percent and were the main factor in keeping the overall rate elevated.

item.title: Russia’s border region with Ukraine is shelled again, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim

item.title: For King Charles’s Coronation, a Fancy Fish Pie Without the Fish
item.description: For most coronations over the past 800 years, the city of Gloucester in England has presented newly crowned monarchs with lamprey pies. Charles’s pie was different.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Berlin Confronts Russian Spies Hiding in Plain Sight
item.description: For years, Germany seemed to tolerate even flagrant Russian operations on its soil. But a new Cold War-like chill has now made the snooping difficult to ignore.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: The Russian Embassy in Berlin in 2021.

item.title: Palestinian Detainee Dies in Israeli Prison After Hunger Strike
item.description: Khader Adnan had led a hunger-strike movement among Palestinians to protest detentions. Palestinian leaders and armed groups blamed Israel for his death, and claimed responsibility for rocket strikes in response.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Women mourning in Jenin on Tuesday after the death of Khader Adnan.

item.title: At a U.N. event on press freedom, the publisher of The New York Times warns of dangers to democracy.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Mele and Andrea Kannapell
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter, has been detained in Russia for more than a month on charges of espionage that the U.S. rejects.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The sale of First Republic Bank.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: People walk past the First Republic bank building in downtown San Francisco Monday morning after the bank was taken over by JPMorgan Chase.

item.title: Facial Recognition Powers ‘Automated Apartheid’ in Israel, Report Says
item.description: The Israeli government is using computer vision to monitor Palestinian travel across checkpoints, according to the report.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Paul Mozur
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier under a surveillance camera at a checkpoint in Hebron in 2021.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Step Up Attacks Amid Signs That Counteroffensive Is Near
item.description: Russian forces were reportedly moving into defensive positions, as Ukraine’s defense chief said the military was “reaching the finish line” for a major push to reclaim occupied land.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A residential area hit by a Russian strike in Pavlograd, Ukraine on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Marcos at the White House
item.description: Also, Russian attacks across Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden and First Lady Dr. Jill Biden greeted Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. President of the Republic of the Philippines and Mrs. Louise Araneta-Marcos, at the White House on Monday.

item.title: In Israel, McCarthy Pledges Continued Support for Ukraine
item.description: The speaker, who warned last year that there would be no “blank check” for Ukraine, told a Russian reporter he would continue support to Kyiv against Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Kevin McCarthy, the California Republican who became House speaker in January, addressed Israeli lawmakers in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Says 100,000 Russian Casualties in Ukraine in Past 5 Months
item.description: About half of the reported dead were mercenaries for the Wagner group, a paramilitary force that recruited heavily from Russian prisons.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abandoned Russian tank in the forest in the village of Ruski Tyshky, north of Kharkiv, Ukraine, in January.

item.title: McCarthy Offers to Host Netanyahu in Washington After Biden Refuses
item.description: The House speaker, Kevin McCarthy, made the informal invitation during a visit to the Israeli Parliament, which came after President Biden had declined to invite the Israeli leader to Washington.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, left, with Kevin McCarthy, the House speaker, center, and the speaker of the Israeli Parliament, Amir Ohana, in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: Keshub Mahindra, Billionaire Indian Industrialist, Dies at 99
item.description: He expanded a family steel and jeep business into an international leviathan, but his career was stained by a conviction in the 1984 Bhopal disaster.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Keshub Mahindra leaving court in Bhopal, India, in 2010, after being convicted of negligence in one of the world’s worst industrial disasters.
